content: Approx. 450 enslaved people in Connecticut
Notes: Source: https://glc.yale.edu/sites/default/files/files/Citizens%20All%20Doc2.pdf

content: First Anti-Slavery Article published in New England (The Selling of Joseph)
Notes: Judge Samuel Sewall publishes a pamphlet entitled The Selling of Joseph

content: Carolina Assembly passed curfew law for black people
Notes: first comprehensive slave law in Carolina was established in 1696, if we were to extend a few years early of the timeline

content: An Act Relating to Slavery: Liability for former Masters to pay living expenses for freed slaves
Act to establish brick lazaratto on Sullivan's House to quarantine people (most of whom were enslaved people)
Notes: an estimated 200,000 total of African slaves quarantined in the lazarettos

content: CT law passed forbidding enslaved people from selling goods to whites
Notes: Source, pg. 64: https://digitalrepository.trincoll.edu/cgi/viewcontent.cgi?article=1006&context=hartford_papers

content: A report by governor Johnson show that the SC colony had 4,100 enslaved blacks and 1,400 enslaved Indians (>3960 free white people)
Notes: accurate? used to promote colony's posperity

content: Blacks outnumber whites in South Carolina
Notes: Source: https://www.thirteen.org/wnet/slavery/timeline/1705.html

content: "Vendue Master" title created
Notes: in whom the legal power to auction within the town is concentrated

content: The Assembly merged SC's militiamen and slave patrols
Notes: de facto a militia to control the enslaved

content: Assembly passed new Negro Act regarding execution of slave conspirators
Notes: following two uncovered conspiracies and a widespread fear of insurrection

content: 1490 enslaved people in CT
Notes: Source: https://glc.yale.edu/sites/default/files/files/Citizens%20All%20Doc2.pdf

content: Import duty on slaves provided half of the colony's operating revenue
Congregational church body in CT determines that enslaved children can be baptized
Notes: Source: Piersen, 54

content: The Stono Rebellion
Indigenous enslavement outlawed in South Carolina
SC passes "Negro Act," forbidding learning to read English, assembling freely, growing food, etc.
New York Conspiracy
Old Light ministers of CT decide that enslaved congregants may not vote in church matters
Notes: Source: Piersen, 50

content: about 12,000 black Africans imported into Charleston
Notes: due to wartime scarcity and soaring price of commodities, Fraser Jr., 96

content: Philadelphia Quaker yearly meeting votes to exclude members who bought or sold enslaved people
Notes: Litwack, 12

content: 4590 enslaved people in CT
Notes: Source: https://glc.yale.edu/sites/default/files/files/Citizens%20All%20Doc2.pdf

content: Black Election Day Festival common in Hartford (annual ceremonial election of a "King")
Notes: Source: Piersen, 118

content: Charleston Non-Importation Agreement
Notes: local boycott lifted in December 1770 with the support of merchants and planters

content: Sally George carrying 345 enslaved people was refused permission to land them
Around half of CT's doctors, lawyers, and professional people owned enslaved people
Notes: WHS article: https://windsorhistoricalsociety.org/chaffee-house-reopens/

content: Around half of CT's black population lived in New London and Fairfield counties
Notes: Source: William Piersen, 15.

content: CT Nonimportation Act
Notes: Morgan, 907

content: Lowcountry descendents were worth an average of £2,700
Notes: more than six times of that of the other 12 colonies

content: Enslaved people accounted for 68% of the movable wealth in South Carolina
Sugar House convered to Work House
Notes: primarily used to punish enslaved people

content: PA Society for the Abolition of Slavery established
Thomas Jeremiah hanged
Total enslaved population of the colonies is nearly half a million people
Notes: https://www.thirteen.org/wnet/slavery/timeline/1773.html

content: Some 93,000 people imported into the colony between 1706-75
Notes: 35,000 before 1750, and 58,000 durinh 1750-1775, Morgan, 905

content: 6,464 enslaved people in CT (largest # of any state in New England)
Notes: WHS article: https://windsorhistoricalsociety.org/chaffee-house-reopens/

content: Declaration of Independence
first enslaved persons petition General Assembly for the abolition of slavery in CT.
Notes: Prime and Prince are the first two enslaved people to petition

content: "Vendue Master" title abolished, began offering auction licenses
Gradual Abolition Act passed in Pennsylvania/ first Abolition Act in America?
Elizabeth Freeman's freedom suit in MA
Quock Walker freedom suit in MA
Black population of Hartford County (CT): 1320
Notes: Source: Piersen, 163

content: CT Gradual Emancipation Act
Notes: Act passed providing for emancipation at age of twenty-five of all African-Americans born after March 1784 (actually 25 for men and 21 for women); CT was the second state to pass this abolition act

content: Wilson v. Hinkley (CT Superior Court ruling that free blacks [born of a free woman] cannot be enslaved)
Free African Society established by Absalom Jones and Richard Allen
Act prohibiting slave trade from any source
CT residents prohibited from participating in the slave trade
Notes: Source: https://www.thirteen.org/wnet/slavery/timeline/1788.html

content: Constitution ratified
Between 1790-1860, slave traders in USA moved 1,000,000 slaves from Upper South to  Lower South, producing $12,000,000 annually.
Notes: This trade benefited middle-class occupations in the South, as well as the expansion of northeastern textile mills.

content: Census records show that CT had around 2,771 "free non-whites" and 2764 enslaved people
Notes: The majority of them were born BEFORE 1784. Actually, the "free non-white" population was 2,771

content: Black population of Hartford County (CT): 693
Notes: Source: Piersen, 163

content: Census records show that SC had 107,094 enslaved people (43% of state population)
CT legislature rejects bill that would have abolished slavery in the state in 1795
Eli Whitney patented the cotton gin
1797 act modified the GEA and reduced gradual emancipation act to age 21, dismantled state's Slave Code as well
Formerly Enslaved Venture Smith's authobiography is published including accounts of life in Africa, slavery, and freedom.
Notes: Earliest autobiography by an African-American. Lived in Haddam Neck? First Published American Slave Narrative.

content: "Old" santee canal built, which was built by slaves to connect Charleston and Colombia
Notes: (connected charleston SC and colombia) (built by "laborers" (mostly slaves))

content: 951 enslaved people in CT (census)
Notes: WHS article: https://windsorhistoricalsociety.org/chaffee-house-reopens/

content: 36,505 enslaved Black Americans in the north
Notes: Litwack, 3

content: The beginning of the expansion of the "Cotton Frontier": the westward expansion of public land in the name of growing cotton
Notes: As the demand for cotton grew, so did the westward expansion/destribution of public land in the name of growing cotton

content: SC resumed importation of slaves until banned in 1808
Ban on importation of slaves
Nominal slave prices in SC are now at $414.33
Notes: this is the last year shown on the data table of probate inventories (this demonstrates an immense increase in slave prices in SC from 1722-1809. Slaves were the majority of the pop. and labor force as well during these years.

content: Census records show that CT had around 6500 free blacks and 310 enslaved people
Notes: 1800 had the free non-white poulation as 8,268, but the 1810 cencus had free non-white as 6,453. Total population in 1800 was 64,273; total population in 1810 was 261,942. Did free black people relocate?

content: Charleston ordinance sets lower limits for appearances of enslaved people (no irons, must be sufficiently clothed, etc)
Notes: Miles, 137.

content: exports from SC in 1816 was valued $10,849,409, mainly cotton, second to NY's export
Notes: Fraser cites Courier, postwar boom in rice and cotton

content: Establishment of American Colonization Society
Windsor v. Hartford case involving slave/free status of Fanny Libbet of Windsor
Notes: Complex, significant case--and link to Dr. Hez. Chaffee, as Libbet's mother was Sarah, enslaved by him and manumitted in 1801

content: Connecticut’s new constitution specifically bans African-Americans from voting
The panic of 1819: The price of cotton plummets which causes a financial panic
Notes: The price of cotton plummets which causes a financial panic that lead to a depression that lasts until 1823 (shows that cotton is vital to US economy)

content: Census records show that CT had 97 enslaved persons
SC Manumission law--enslavers must seek approval from state legislature
Notes: Miles, 102

content: Enslaved people required to wear identification badges in public in Charleston
Notes: Source: https://www.thirteen.org/wnet/slavery/timeline/1820.html

content: Denmark Vesey's suppressed revolt
City Council demolished AME Church
Law requiring all free Black males >15yo to take a white guardian or sold into slavery
Negro Seaman Act
Publication of David Walker's Appeal
Census records show that CT had more than 8000 and 25 enslaved people
Notes: (Will look for the actual figure)

content: Bales of cotton picked skyrocket 731% compared to numbers from 29 years ago
3,568 enslaved Black Americans in the North
Notes: Litwack, 14

content: Slaveholding southwestern states took almost half of Second Bank of the United States' business.
Notes: https://www.nytimes.com/interactive/2019/08/14/magazine/slavery-capitalism.html the states took over once the Second Bank of USA began investing heavily in cotton.

content: First issue of The Liberator co-published by Garrison
Failed Attempt to establish Black school in New Haven, CT
Nat Turner's rebellion
Black student Charles Ray enrolls at Wesleyan, agrees to leave after pressure
Notes: Litwack pg 117: both southern and northern students objected. School was still new, so in a precarious position

content: Textile companies made up 88 out of 106 American corporations valued at over $100,000.
Notes: https://courses.lumenlearning.com/suny-ushistory1ay/chapter/the-decline-of-northern-slavery-and-the-rise-of-the-cotton-kingdom/

content: The Black Law of Connecticut passes, preventing African Americans from coming into Connecticut to get an education
Notes: Prudence Crandall opened a school for "young misses of color" in Canterbury, Connecticut in 1833, town protested. General Assembly passed the Black Law in 1834, which restricted African Americans from coming into Connecticut to get an education and prohibited anyone from opening a school to educate African Americans from outside the state without getting a town's permission

content: American Anti-Slavery Society (the Society) formed by William Lloyd Garrison
Notes: Notable members frequent speakers included former slaves Frederick Douglass and William Wells Brown.

content: Prudence Crandall's school established in Canterbury, CT
CT Chief Justice David Daggett declared that Black Americans "are not citizens."
